update.description:
This pull request adds a GPS sensor and two supporting classes. It includes tests and an example world `test/worlds/gps_test.world` with gps sensors attached to pendulums.

`common::SphericalCoordinates` is a class for converting from Cartesian to spherical coordinates.

`sensors::Noise` is a class that can be used for adding noise to sensors. Currently several sensors are implementing sensor noise in their own way. This class is my proposal for reusing that code, which greatly simplifies the sdf definitions and testing. 

Depends on [sdformat pull request 36](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/36).
update.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

pull_request.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

pullrequest.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

content.raw: You're right and now I know one more class :)
content.html: You're right and now I know one more class :)

pullrequest.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

content.raw: I just responded to some of those comments about units. I don't think it's necessary to specify units if I use the `math::Angle` class.
content.html: I just responded to some of those comments about units. I don't think it's necessary to specify units if I use the math::Angle class.

pull_request.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

pullrequest.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

content.raw: I see, math::Angle just represents the abstract angle and then you can get the units that you prefer. You're right!
content.html: I see, math::Angle just represents the abstract angle and then you can get the units that you prefer. You're right!

content.raw:
I'd prefer to use the defaults as specified in the sdf description.

I just looked, and it appears that [GetElement always returns a valid ElementPtr](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/ee8d128f4e2cc5089c436a3a3c881c110c163d89/src/SDF.cc#cl-728). So I could simplify this code, I guess.
content.html:
I'd prefer to use the defaults as specified in the sdf description.

I just looked, and it appears that GetElement always returns a valid ElementPtr. So I could simplify this code, I guess.

pull_request.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

pullrequest.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

content.raw: Use `_GAZEBO_NOISE_HH_`. There is a chance another application uses `_NOISE_HH_`.
content.html: Use _GAZEBO_NOISE_HH_. There is a chance another application uses _NOISE_HH_.

pull_request.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

pullrequest.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

content.raw: I think `GetElement` will always return a valid Element pointer. If the element is not specified, then default values will be used. Not sure if that is what you want.
content.html: I think GetElement will always return a valid Element pointer. If the element is not specified, then default values will be used. Not sure if that is what you want.

content.raw: I was trying to avoid an sdformat dependency in common. I guess SphericalCoordinates could be moved to physics. I'll defer to your opinion.
content.html: I was trying to avoid an sdformat dependency in common. I guess SphericalCoordinates could be moved to physics. I'll defer to your opinion.

content.raw: Does it make sense to add `SphericalCoordinates::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)`, instead of processing the sdf in World?
content.html: Does it make sense to add SphericalCoordinates::Load(sdf::ElementPtr _sdf), instead of processing the sdf in World?
